item.title: First F-16 fighter jets have arrived in Ukraine, Zelensky confirms
item.dc:creator: David Stern
item.description: The planes are unlikely to fly near the front lines, officials said, as there are too few of them — and too many Russian defense systems that can shoot them down.

item.title: Far-right protesters attack hotel housing asylum seekers in violent weekend
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih, Ben Brasch, Adela Suliman, Dan Rosenzweig-Ziff
item.description: Demonstrations in Rotherham, Liverpool, Hull and Bristol turned violent, prompting arrests. Misinformation about a deadly knife attack in Southport, England, spurred far-right protests.

item.title: Dozens killed as anti-government protests resume in Bangladesh
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan, Azad Majumder
item.description: A nationwide curfew was imposed in Bangladesh as fresh protests in the country turned violent.

item.title: Strikes in Gaza, stabbing near Tel Aviv amid fears of wider Mideast war
item.dc:creator: Heidi Levine, Annabelle Timsit, Andrew Jeong, Hajar Harb
item.description: At least 30 people were killed in Israeli strikes at schools housing displaced people, Gazan authorities said. The IDF said the schools were used by Hamas.

item.title: Israeli raids in West Bank cities help fuel militant violence
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker, Lorenzo Tugnoli
item.description: In the city of Jenin, the impact of the raids — and their role in fueling Palestinian militancy — is especially stark.

item.title: Death of Hamas chief draws mixed reactions in war-battered Gaza
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Hajar Harb
item.description: By the time Ismail Haniyeh was killed early Wednesday in Tehran, he had traded his humble life in Gaza for a more comfortable perch abroad.

item.title: Iran gives first detailed statement on Hamas leader’s killing
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Victoria Bisset, Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh was killed by a short-range projectile, Iran’s Revolutionary Guards said in Tehran’s first detailed statement on the assassination.

item.title: Taiwan is readying citizens for a Chinese invasion. It’s not going well.
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd, Vic Chiang
item.description: The government extended mandatory military service and revamped reservist training in an effort to make Beijing think twice. But it’s already falling short.

item.title: They were in prison in the West. Now they’re celebrities in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch, Mikhail Klimentov
item.description: For Russians returning home in a prisoner swap, time spent in an American prison can be a great career move.

item.title: How many hostages are still in Gaza since Hamas attack on Israel? What to know.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Sammy Westfall, Helier Cheung
item.description: Israel estimates some 116 hostages held by Hamas have been released or freed; 72 are believed still to be alive in Gaza. Here’s what we know.

item.title: Left and right have denounced Venezuela’s Maduro. Not the authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: Terrence McCoy
item.description: After the strongman claimed reelection Sunday, even leftist allies distanced themselves. Russia, China, Iran and Cuba continue to stand by their man.

item.title: Al Jazeera rejects Israeli allegation that slain journalist was Hamas fighter
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Hajar Harb, Chris Dehghanpoor
item.description: Ismail al-Ghoul, the channel’s Gaza correspondent, was killed in an Israeli airstrike this week. Al Jazeera said allegations that he was a member of Hamas’s military wing are “baseless.”

item.title: U.S. forces move toward Israel as Iran threatens to attack
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: The Pentagon has relocated several warships in recent days as Iran threatens to attack Israel and avenge the killing of key leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah.

item.title: After assassinations, Israel braces for retaliation, wider conflict
item.dc:creator: Missy Ryan, Heidi Levine, Alon Rom, Miriam Berger
item.description: In the space of 24 hours this week, each of Israel’s chief adversaries vowed to deal the Jewish state a searing, potentially unprecedented blow.

item.title: Homeland Security Dept. pauses Biden parole program for four countries
item.dc:creator: Maria Sacchetti
item.description: The Biden administration said it paused a program that admits up to 360,000 people a year from four countries into the United States to work or seek asylum.
